criteria.name: Audience Fit and Tailoring
criteria.description: Assesses how well the summary targets and serves its intended user types (e.g., legal professionals, students, policymakers, laypersons) based solely on the text. Evaluates alignment of detail, terminology, and explanations with the stated or clearly implied audience and usage context.

sub_criteria.name: Target User Identification
sub_criteria.description: Whether the summary explicitly states or clearly implies who it is for and the intended usage context.

sub_criteria.name: Jargon Level Appropriateness
sub_criteria.description: Alignment of legal terminology density and complexity with the stated or implied audience.

sub_criteria.name: Explanations and Definitions
sub_criteria.description: Provision of brief definitions or clarifications for non-obvious terms needed for comprehension by the audience.

sub_criteria.name: Layering for Mixed Audiences
sub_criteria.description: Use of plain-language sections, tiered detail, or summaries to serve both novice and expert readers when applicable.

sub_criteria.name: Assumed Prior Knowledge Calibration
sub_criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary’s content assumes an appropriate level of prior legal knowledge for the audience.

criteria.name: Coverage of Essential Case Elements
criteria.description: Evaluates presence and clarity of core components needed to understand the case from the summary alone: parties, material facts, issues, rules, holding, reasoning, procedural posture, disposition/remedy, and any separate opinions.

sub_criteria.name: Parties and Roles
sub_criteria.description: Identification of parties and their roles (e.g., plaintiff/defendant, appellant/appellee).

sub_criteria.name: Material Facts
sub_criteria.description: Inclusion of dispositive facts necessary to understand the decision.

sub_criteria.name: Issues/Questions Presented
sub_criteria.description: Clear articulation of the legal issue(s) addressed by the court.

sub_criteria.name: Rule/Legal Standard
sub_criteria.description: Statement of the governing rule(s) or standard(s) applied.

sub_criteria.name: Standard of Review
sub_criteria.description: Statement of the appellate or decision-making standard applied (e.g., de novo, abuse of discretion) when applicable.

sub_criteria.name: Holding
sub_criteria.description: Court’s answer to each issue, stated clearly and specifically.

sub_criteria.name: Reasoning/Rationale
sub_criteria.description: Key steps in the court’s analysis supporting the holding, concise and traceable.

sub_criteria.name: Procedural Posture/History
sub_criteria.description: Status and path of the case when decided (e.g., on appeal, remand, motion stage).

sub_criteria.name: Disposition/Remedy
sub_criteria.description: Outcome (e.g., affirmed, reversed) and remedies/damages if applicable and stated in the summary.

sub_criteria.name: Separate Opinions (if applicable)
sub_criteria.description: Noting concurrences/dissents and their central points when present in the summary.

criteria.name: Actionability for Intended Use
criteria.description: Evaluates whether the summary provides practical takeaways aligned with the intended user tasks (e.g., compliance choices, litigation strategy cues, study notes), based solely on the summary’s content.

sub_criteria.name: Practical Implications
sub_criteria.description: Explicit statements of what changes or matters for the user as a result of the case.

sub_criteria.name: Use Cases/Examples
sub_criteria.description: Illustrative scenarios showing how the rule/holding applies in practice, when appropriate for the audience.

sub_criteria.name: Next Steps/Decision Guidance
sub_criteria.description: Concrete options or considerations the user should weigh (e.g., preserve issue, adjust policy, gather evidence).

sub_criteria.name: Risk/Uncertainty Flags
sub_criteria.description: Clear flagging of ambiguities, split authority signals, or unresolved questions as described in the summary itself (presence noted, not externally verified).

criteria.name: Clarity and Readability
criteria.description: Assesses writing clarity, precision, and readability appropriate to the audience, including avoidance of vague language and unnecessary complexity.

sub_criteria.name: Sentence Clarity
sub_criteria.description: Straightforward sentences without convoluted structure.

sub_criteria.name: Specificity and Precision
sub_criteria.description: Avoids vague qualifiers; uses concrete, specific phrasing (e.g., states outcomes and conditions).

sub_criteria.name: Terminology and Acronyms Defined
sub_criteria.description: Defines specialized terms and acronyms when needed for comprehension by the intended audience.

sub_criteria.name: Readability Level vs Audience
sub_criteria.description: Overall readability level appropriate to the target audience (e.g., novice vs expert).

criteria.name: Structure and Navigability
criteria.description: Evaluates organization for easy scanning and retrieval, including logical sectioning, headings, ordering, and internal cross-references.

sub_criteria.name: Logical Flow
sub_criteria.description: Elements appear in a coherent, expected order (e.g., facts -> issues -> rule -> analysis -> holding -> disposition).

sub_criteria.name: Headings and Signposting
sub_criteria.description: Clear section titles and transitions for quick navigation.

sub_criteria.name: Skimmability
sub_criteria.description: Use of bullets, lists, or summaries to enable quick grasp of key points.

sub_criteria.name: Cross-Referencing Within Summary
sub_criteria.description: Clear references within the summary (e.g., 'see Reasoning') that help readers locate related details without redundancy.

sub_criteria.name: Summary-at-a-Glance
sub_criteria.description: Presence of a brief TL;DR or key takeaways section at the top or end.

criteria.name: Objectivity and Balance
criteria.description: Assesses neutrality in tone and balanced presentation of parties’ positions and the court’s analysis, with clear separation between objective summary and any commentary.

sub_criteria.name: Neutral Tone
sub_criteria.description: Avoids loaded language and subjective judgments in the summary portions.

sub_criteria.name: Balanced Presentation
sub_criteria.description: Fairly represents key arguments from both sides as described in the summary content.

sub_criteria.name: Separation of Facts and Commentary
sub_criteria.description: Any analysis or opinion is clearly labeled and separated from neutral case description.

criteria.name: Citation and Source Anchoring
criteria.description: Evaluates how the summary anchors statements to identifiable case details and citations. Only the presence and clarity of identifiers and references are assessed; no external verification.

sub_criteria.name: Case Identification Completeness
sub_criteria.description: Presence of case name, reporter/docket, court, and decision date within the summary.

sub_criteria.name: Citation Consistency
sub_criteria.description: Uniform, readable citation formatting throughout the summary.

sub_criteria.name: Pinpoint References/Quotations
sub_criteria.description: Pinpoints or brief quotations for dispositive rules/holdings when helpful for users, as provided in the summary.

sub_criteria.name: Precedential Status Signaling
sub_criteria.description: States whether the decision is binding or persuasive and the court level, if indicated by the summary; presence assessed without external verification.

sub_criteria.name: Statutory/Regulatory Anchoring
sub_criteria.description: Presence of references to statutes/regulations when central to the decision (as stated within the summary), without external verification.
accepted_values: Exemplary (5) — Central statutes/regulations named with sections.

criteria.name: Conciseness and Information Density
criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary delivers maximum useful content with minimal redundancy and digression, based on the text itself.

sub_criteria.name: Redundancy Avoidance
sub_criteria.description: Minimizes repeated statements unless for emphasis or clarity.

sub_criteria.name: Essential vs. Optional Detail Balance
sub_criteria.description: Prioritizes dispositive points over peripheral commentary.

sub_criteria.name: Signal-to-Noise Ratio
sub_criteria.description: Proportion of sentences conveying actionable or essential information versus filler.
accepted_values: Exemplary (5) — Nearly every sentence adds value.
Adequate (3) — Mixed value; many neutral sentences.

sub_criteria.name: Length Appropriateness vs Use
sub_criteria.description: Overall length is appropriate for the intended purpose and audience.
accepted_values: Exemplary (5) — Length optimized for use-case and audience.

criteria.name: Internal Consistency and Logical Coherence
criteria.description: Evaluates whether elements within the summary align without contradictions and whether the logic from issues to holding is coherent.

sub_criteria.name: Issue–Rule–Holding Alignment
sub_criteria.description: Stated rules and holdings directly address the framed issues.

sub_criteria.name: Procedural Consistency
sub_criteria.description: Procedural posture and disposition align with the described history in the summary.

sub_criteria.name: Terminology Consistency
sub_criteria.description: Party names, abbreviations, and terms are used consistently throughout.
accepted_values: Adequate (3) — Several inconsistencies; context reveals meaning.

sub_criteria.name: Temporal Sequence Consistency
sub_criteria.description: Events and procedural steps maintain a coherent temporal order.

criteria.name: Self-Containment and Contextualization
criteria.description: Assesses whether a reader unfamiliar with the case can understand its significance and boundaries from the summary alone, including scope, assumptions, and why the case matters.

sub_criteria.name: Background Context
sub_criteria.description: Minimal necessary background provided to frame the issues and facts.

sub_criteria.name: Significance/Why It Matters
sub_criteria.description: Explains the decision’s importance or impact as stated within the summary (e.g., clarification, new standard).

sub_criteria.name: Scope and Limitations
sub_criteria.description: States boundaries and conditions of applicability; distinguishes what the case does not decide, if described by the summary.

criteria.name: Reusability and Extractability
criteria.description: Evaluates how easily the summary’s content can be reused in downstream workflows (e.g., outlines, knowledge bases) through standardized labels, metadata, and formatting patterns.

sub_criteria.name: Standardized Section Labels
sub_criteria.description: Use of conventional headings (e.g., Facts, Issue, Rule, Holding, Reasoning, Disposition).

sub_criteria.name: Key Metadata Presence
sub_criteria.description: Presence of extractable fields (case name, court, date, citation) within the summary text with clear labeling.

sub_criteria.name: List and Bullet Use for Key Points
sub_criteria.description: Use of lists/tables for rules, factors, or elements to aid extraction.
accepted_values: Exemplary (5) — Lists used for all multi-part elements.
Strong (4) — Lists used for most multi-part elements.
Weak (2) — Rare or ineffective list use.

sub_criteria.name: Formatting Consistency for Extraction
sub_criteria.description: Consistency of typography, numbering, and label patterns that facilitate automated or manual extraction.

criteria.name: Jurisdictional and Practice Relevance Signaling
criteria.description: Assesses whether the summary helps readers quickly determine relevance to their jurisdiction and practice area based solely on the summary’s own content.

sub_criteria.name: Practice Area Tagging/Keywords
sub_criteria.description: Presence of explicit practice area labels or keywords (e.g., contracts, criminal procedure).

sub_criteria.name: Jurisdictional Scope/Applicability
sub_criteria.description: Clarity on geographic or court-level scope of applicability (e.g., state vs federal; circuit/region).

sub_criteria.name: Subsequent Treatment/Currentness Signals
sub_criteria.description: Mentions within the summary of subsequent history, split authority, or noted changes affecting reliance (presence only; no external verification).

sub_criteria.name: Statutory/Regulatory Domain Cues
sub_criteria.description: Indication of implicated statutes/regulations and practice subdomain (e.g., ERISA, Title VII) as stated in the summary.
